course.subject: MARK
course.name: Judgment and Decision Making for Marketers
course.description: This course covers both normative and psychological aspects of decision making with specific reference to marketing and consumer decisions. The course will introduce the building blocks of decision making such as belief and utility assessment and will contrast the economic models of decision making with psychological models that take into account various biases in judgments and choices. The course will also introduce experimental design and analysis relevant for marketing decisions and will discuss the marketing applications of behavioral decision research.

Many calculations but actually similar with the basic stuff taught in isom2500 (ANOVA, probability). Most of the chapters just have calculation problems, but they are not too hard, just memorize formula then you will be fine. While a few other chapters require memorization, but they are about some psychological theories so it is quite interesting.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof has an Indian accent. Some may find it difficult to understand. He also teach on notes and textbook questions in class (but not ppt) and never turned on the projector in class. So sometimes we are quite lost where he is talking about lol. But overall he teaches well, and you can always read the textbook yourself when you don't understand.

reviews.comment_workload:
3 quizzes throughout the semester
1 group presentation (15 min, just analyse an article assigned and present the findings and implications)
1 project (5-8 page write-up, only prepare simple questionnaire)

Overall, I think it is just a normal 3-cred course workload. I believe it is a relatively-light workload MARK course.
